articles.headline: Making Sure the Negative Can Be Heard
articles.snippet: Companies that sue their critics are no friends of free speech.
articles.abstract: Companies that sue their critics are no friends of free speech.
articles.lead_paragraph: “If my attorneys knew I was here, they would be here with a hook,” joked David A. Rocker a few weeks ago, looking out at a sea of people some 1,600 strong.

articles.headline: Giuliani Takes On G.O.P. Orthodoxy on Social Issues
articles.snippet: Rudolph W. Giuliani said that Republicans needed to be tolerant of dissenting views on abortion rights, gun control and gay rights to retain the White House.
articles.abstract: Rudolph W. Giuliani said that Republicans needed to be tolerant of dissenting views on abortion rights, gun control and gay rights to retain the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, May 11 — Rudolph W. Giuliani directly challenged Republican orthodoxy on Friday, asserting that his support for abortion rights, gun control and gay rights should not disqualify him from winning the party’s presidential nomination.
articles.byline: By Marc Santora and Adam Nagourney

articles.headline: Billions in Oil Missing in Iraq, U.S. Study Says
articles.snippet: The report reinforced longstanding suspicions that smugglers, insurgents and corrupt officials control significant parts of the country’s oil industry.
articles.abstract: The report reinforced longstanding suspicions that smugglers, insurgents and corrupt officials control significant parts of the country’s oil industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Between 100,000 and 300,000 barrels a day of Iraq’s declared oil production over the past four years is unaccounted for and could have been siphoned off through corruption or smuggling, according to a draft American government report.

articles.headline: Incredible Shrinking Packages
articles.snippet: More companies are cutting down on packaging to reduce expenses and address growing environmental concerns.
articles.abstract: More companies are cutting down on packaging to reduce expenses and address growing environmental concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: Marketers usually boast about what they have added to their products. Increasingly, though, they are bragging about what they are taking out — by cutting down on packaging and its impact on the environment.

articles.headline: Hands on the Wheel, Not on the BlackBerry Keys
articles.snippet: More legislators are worried about the dangers of driving while texting with a BlackBerry or other mobile device.
articles.abstract: More legislators are worried about the dangers of driving while texting with a BlackBerry or other mobile device.
articles.lead_paragraph: Do u txt whl drvng?

articles.headline: Suspicious Trading on the Rise
articles.snippet: Regulators are again knee-deep in insider trading cases, with profiteers spanning the globe, from Hong Kong to lower Manhattan.
articles.abstract: Regulators are again knee-deep in insider trading cases, with profiteers spanning the globe, from Hong Kong to lower Manhattan.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Wall Street, it feels like the 1980s all over again. Investment banks and private equity firms are minting money on a binge of deal making. Buyouts are not only back, but bigger than ever. Billionaire titans of finance are feted at huge, glittering parties. Even leggings are back in style.

articles.headline: A Contrarian on Retirement Says Wait
articles.snippet: An economics professor suggests that retirees should delay collecting Social Security benefits to maximize their returns.
articles.abstract: An economics professor suggests that retirees should delay collecting Social Security benefits to maximize their returns.
articles.lead_paragraph: Come retirement, it will finally be time to get back the money that has been extracted from your paycheck your entire working life.

articles.headline: Civilian Deaths Undermine Allies’ War on Taliban
articles.snippet: Deaths from American and allied airstrikes are threatening popular support for the Afghan government and straining the NATO alliance.
articles.abstract: Deaths from American and allied airstrikes are threatening popular support for the Afghan government and straining the NATO alliance.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZERKOH, Afghanistan, May 9 — Scores of civilian deaths over the past months from heavy American and allied reliance on airstrikes to battle Taliban insurgents are threatening popular support for the Afghan government and creating severe strains within the NATO alliance.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Religious Groups Reap Federal Aid for Pet Projects
articles.snippet: Earmarks for religious organizations have increased sharply, and some of the groups have hired lobbyists.
articles.abstract: Earmarks for religious organizations have increased sharply, and some of the groups have hired lobbyists.
articles.lead_paragraph: St. Vincent College, a small Benedictine college southeast of Pittsburgh, wanted to realign a two-lane state road serving the campus. But the state transportation department did not have the money.
articles.byline: By Diana B. Henriques and Andrew W. Lehren

articles.headline: In New Role, Senator Clinton’s Strategist in Chief
articles.snippet: Bill Clinton is the master strategist behind his wife’s candidacy, but there are potential pitfalls to his presence.
articles.abstract: Bill Clinton is the master strategist behind his wife’s candidacy, but there are potential pitfalls to his presence.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bill Clinton’s connections, and his endless supply of chits, only begin to capture his singular role in his wife’s presidential candidacy, advisers and friends of the couple say. He is the master strategist behind the scenes; the consigliere to the head of “the family,” as some Clinton aides refer to her operation; and a fund-raising machine who is steadily pulling in $100,000 or more at receptions.

articles.headline: Tilting at a Digital Future
articles.snippet: As is so often the case with Rupert Murdoch, his bid for Dow Jones is counterintuitive and seemingly quixotic.
articles.abstract: As is so often the case with Rupert Murdoch, his bid for Dow Jones is counterintuitive and seemingly quixotic.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN Rupert Murdoch’s world, two things are certain: the sun never sets on the kingdom, and a TV is always on in the background.

articles.headline: Managers and Investors, Well Met
articles.snippet: Markel does not avoid or abuse its shareholders; it serves them.
articles.abstract: Markel does not avoid or abuse its shareholders; it serves them.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT’S annual meeting season, and for many corporate executives that means picking through picketers, getting a grilling from gadflies, and sizing up snarky shareholders.

articles.headline: The Greatest Mystery: Making a Best Seller
articles.snippet: The advance is usually the estimate of the first year's royalties. It's often wrong.
articles.abstract: The advance is usually the estimate of the first year's royalties. It's often wrong.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN Shana Kelly, a literary agent at the William Morris Agency, submitted Curtis Sittenfeld’s first novel, “Cipher,” to book publishers in 2003, she had high expectations. She contacted nearly two dozen high-ranking editors at major publishers, expecting every one to make offers for her client’s coming-of-age story set at a boarding school.

articles.headline: Today’s Face of Abortion in China Is a Young, Unmarried Woman
articles.snippet: Abortion is no longer just associated with married women complying with the country’s one-child policy.
articles.abstract: Abortion is no longer just associated with married women complying with the country’s one-child policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: QINGDAO, China — At an abortion clinic in this seaside city, a young woman sat in the recovery room with an IV drip in one hand and a cellphone in the other. She was 22 and worked as a nurse. Her boyfriend, an information technology specialist, sat nearby. They both knew the routine: It was her second abortion in 18 months.

articles.headline: Students See the Future, and It’s Elderly People
articles.snippet: The need to find and train people to work with the elderly has become more urgent as the baby boom generation ages and people live longer than ever.
articles.abstract: The need to find and train people to work with the elderly has become more urgent as the baby boom generation ages and people live longer than ever.
articles.lead_paragraph: DANCING to the driving beat of 1960s twist music, the three high school students tried to rouse the spirits of the 50 people in front of them. Some in the audience swayed slightly in their chairs or wheelchairs, or clapped or nodded with the rhythm. Others simply watched; a few dozed despite the high decibels from the live singer and his synthesizer.

articles.headline: Rising Exports Putting Dent in Trade Gap
articles.snippet: It now looks as if the huge U.S. trade deficit, which swelled to a record $765.3 billion last year, could gradually decrease.
articles.abstract: It now looks as if the huge U.S. trade deficit, which swelled to a record $765.3 billion last year, could gradually decrease.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over half of the 9.1 million vehicles General Motors produced last year were sold in foreign countries. More KFC fast food restaurants are opening in China now than in the United States.

articles.headline: At Journal, Slim Margins Open Door to Murdoch
articles.snippet: Lagging profit margins and a poor financial outlook may have made The Wall Street Journal an attractive target.
articles.abstract: Lagging profit margins and a poor financial outlook may have made The Wall Street Journal an attractive target.
articles.lead_paragraph: Does The Wall Street Journal make money? The question might seem silly. The chronicler of capitalism, the bible of business: of course The Journal turns a profit, right?

articles.headline: Less Risk Seen in Purchasing Clothes Online
articles.snippet: For the first time, online retail sales of clothing have overtaken those of computer hardware and software.
articles.abstract: For the first time, online retail sales of clothing have overtaken those of computer hardware and software.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maybe Americans don’t need dressing rooms after all.

articles.headline: Is It the Woman Thing, or Is It Katie Couric?
articles.snippet: “CBS Evening News” is back in third place, but Ms. Couric says she is unfazed, and CBS is continuing to support her.
articles.abstract: “CBS Evening News” is back in third place, but Ms. Couric says she is unfazed, and CBS is continuing to support her.
articles.lead_paragraph: The numbers are stark. Eight months into Katie Couric’s job as the first woman to anchor a network newscast on her own, her “CBS Evening News” has not only settled back into its long-held position of last among the evening news broadcasts, but also regularly falls short of the newscast that Ms. Couric replaced.

articles.headline: Trying to Keep the Viewers When the Ads Come On
articles.snippet: The growing popularity of alternatives to watching TV on sets is forcing networks to change their habits.
articles.abstract: The growing popularity of alternatives to watching TV on sets is forcing networks to change their habits.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the big agencies get ready for the biggest week of the year for the biggest advertising medium, changes are coming that can only be called, well, big.

articles.headline: Chrysler on Verge of Sale to a Private Firm
articles.snippet: A sale to Cerberus Capital Management, which specializes in restructuring troubled companies, could be announced today.
articles.abstract: A sale to Cerberus Capital Management, which specializes in restructuring troubled companies, could be announced today.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT, May 13 — DaimlerChrysler appears close to selling the struggling Chrysler Group to a private equity firm that specializes in restructuring troubled companies, unwinding a 1998 merger that was meant to create a trans-Atlantic automotive powerhouse, people with direct knowledge of the discussions said on Sunday.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Mayor Denies Political Bid but Fuels Talk With Actions
articles.snippet: Michael R. Bloomberg has fueled speculation that he will run for president by sharpening his national profile and delivering speeches across the country.
articles.abstract: Michael R. Bloomberg has fueled speculation that he will run for president by sharpening his national profile and delivering speeches across the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last week, Michael R. Bloomberg, the New York City mayor, stood on a sunny public school terrace in Queens and told reporters that he was not running for president.

articles.headline: Many Cuts and Crises at a Paper
articles.snippet: After a round of buyouts that erased many veteran reporters, the publisher of The Star Tribune in Minneapolis has called for deeper cuts.
articles.abstract: After a round of buyouts that erased many veteran reporters, the publisher of The Star Tribune in Minneapolis has called for deeper cuts.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS, May 13 — Last Thursday afternoon, more than a hundred employees of The Star Tribune in Minneapolis took to the small park across the street, many of then dressed in black or wearing black armbands in what they said was an act of mourning.
